channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Government to Offer Free Fertility Treatments to Create Parsi Baby Boom
item.description: The Jiyo-Parsi Scheme is designed to save the minority community from vanishing in India.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By PRIYANKA PATHAK-NARAIN
item.media:description: Kainaz, right, and Farhad Barucha at their apartment in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: Ukraine’s Prime Minister Hails Deal With Russia
item.description: The prime minister, Mykola Azarov, said the agreement for Moscow to provide $15 billion in loans and a steep discount on natural gas meant financial crisis had been averted.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Lawlessness in Borderlands Taints Myanmar’s Progress
item.description: Northern and eastern areas of the country, long riven by ethnic conflict, pose a stubborn impediment to the government’s hopes for national peace.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Zhang Ziyi Settles Libel Suit and U.S. Website Retracts Story
item.description: A website based in the United States has retracted a series of stories alleging that the Chinese film star Zhang Ziyi slept with powerful men in exchange for money.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The film star Zhang Ziyi reached an undisclosed settlement with the website that alleged she slept with powerful men in exchange for money.

item.title: British Family Rebukes Government Over Surgeon’s Death in Syria
item.description: The British Foreign Office warned Syria that it would hold the government of President Bashar al-Assad responsible.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: An injured Syrian was assisted Tuesday after an airstrike in Aleppo, where a British surgeon had offered care before being jailed.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Chinese Coal Baron Tumbles into Debt
item.description: Last year a Shanxi coal baron, Xing Libin, spent 70 million renminbi on his daughter’s wedding with jet aircraft for guests, Ferraris and pop stars, Chinese media reported. Now he’s 30 billion renminbi in debt, the government says.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A worker levels the coal on a freight train in Taiyuan in northern China's Shanxi province.

item.title: Ronnie Biggs, Great Train Robber, Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Biggs gained international fame for his role in one of Britain’s best-known crimes, the Great Train Robbery of 1963, and his subsequent life on the run.
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX
item.media:description: Mr. Biggs lived as a fugitive for 35 years after his escape from jail while serving a 30-year sentence.

item.title: In Typhoon Area, Kerry Cites Threats of Warming Planet
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry announced additional aid to the Philippines and cited the typhoon as a warning of future extreme weather in a warming world.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: The city of Tacloban, in the central Philippines, is still recovering from Typhoon Haiyan, one of the most powerful storms ever recorded.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Defense Ministry Issues Statement Playing Down Near Collision at Sea
item.description: In its first official statement on the near collision of Chinese and American warships, the ministry refrained from alleging any improper conduct by the American side.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: Indian Parliament Passes Bill Forming Anticorruption Agency
item.description: Setting up such an agency was the central demand of the social activist Anna Hazare in 2010, when his fasts and protests electrified the country.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Robert van Zwieten, C.E.O. of Emerging Markets Private Equity Association
item.description: Mr. van Zwieten discussed the outlook for investor appetite in Indian private equity in the coming year.
item.dc:creator: By RAKESH MANI

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Response to Thomas L. Friedman’s ‘Letter’ to President Xi
item.description: Global Times, a newspaper belonging to the flagship People’s Daily, has responded with apparent frankness to a column by Thomas L. Friedman, who warned against expelling Western journalists for their reporting on China.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Global Times said that Thomas L. Friedman was out of touch with China's security concerns.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Unveils Memorial to Spies in Taiwan
item.description: The monument was unveiled this week as a report emerged that Taiwan and China had discussed an exchange of imprisoned spies.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: A Pageant of Power
item.description: Top party and military officials gathered at an indoor stadium in Pyongyang on Tuesday where they made speeches vowing to uphold Kim Jong-un as their unchallenged top leader
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Uprooted in Central Africa, Too Terrified to Go Back
item.description: Sectarian violence in the Central African Republic has forced 40,000 to huddle into a makeshift camp, mending from wounds and struggling with fears.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: At the airport in Bangui, Central African Republic, shacks shelter residents who fled sectarian violence.

item.title: A Top Iraqi Official’s Advice to Karzai? Take America’s Deal
item.description: With the benefit of hindsight, the Iraqi foreign minister, Hoshyar Zebari, urged President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan to get over his differences with the Americans and sign a security agreement with the United States.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan met with the Iraqi foreign minister, Hoshyar Zebari.

item.title: Three Days of Violence in South Sudan Leave Scores Dead
item.description: At least 75 people were killed, the South Sudanese interior minister said, but Reuters put the figure at at least 400 dead and up to 800 wounded.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Aid Challenge in Syria Mounts for U.N. Official
item.description: Some rights advocates say Valerie Amos, the United Nations relief coordinator, has been too patient with the Syrian government in pushing for access to areas in need.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Valerie Amos, the top United Nations relief official. Ms. Amos is under pressure to be tougher with the Syrian authorities.

item.title: The Lede: Outrage in Italy Over ‘Degrading’ Treatment of Migrants Caught on Video
item.description: Italian officials promised to stop the “degrading treatment” of migrants held in a detention center on the island of Lampedusa, after video showed asylum seekers being forced to stand naked outdoors as guards hosed them down.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,278 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Russia Offers Cash Infusion for Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia would provide $15 billion in loans and a sharp discount on natural gas prices, a bold move in his recent diplomatic battle with the West.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: President Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine, left, and President Vladimir V. Putin during a signing ceremony Tuesday in Moscow.

item.title: Senate Asks C.I.A. to Share Its Report on Interrogations
item.description: The Senate Intelligence Committee has asked the C.I.A. for an internal study that lawmakers believe is broadly critical of the C.I.A.’s detention and interrogation program.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:description: Senator Mark Udall, center, disclosed the existence of the internal C.I.A. report on Tuesday.

item.title: Conflicting Tales on How a Brooklyn Businessman Evaded Bolivian Custody
item.description: Two different stories have emerged about how Jacob Ostreicher, who was jailed in Bolivia, managed to make his way to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH BERGER and WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Jacob Ostreicher, right, with the actor Sean Penn, who lobbied for his freedom.

item.title: Britain Warns Syria After Report of Imprisoned Doctor’s Death
item.description: The family of Dr. Abbas Khan had been expecting his release this week but was informed that he had died.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Amid Chinese Rivalry, Japan Seeks More Muscle
item.description: A new five-year defense plan, described as “proactive pacifism,” calls for acquiring drones and amphibious assault vehicles, and reverses a decade of military spending cuts.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Members of the Japanese infantry at a troop review ceremony on a base in Asaka, near Tokyo.
